##Background on Agglomeration

Agglomeration is \textit{geographic clustering.}
\newline
\newline
Firms benefit in three ways:
\begin{itemize}
  \item{labor pooling}
  \item{input sharing}
  \item{knowledge spillover}
\end{itemize}

##Research Question

Do forces of agglomeration affect nonprofit location decisions?
\newline
\newline
If so, do they cluster enough?

##Ellison and Glaeser Summary
Research Question:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item{Is it possible to create indices of geographic concentration and coagglomeration that control for industry differences?}
  \item{Are observed levels of concentration greater than would be expected to arise randomly?}
\end{enumerate}

##Ellison and Glaeser Agglomeration Metric
\begin{center}
\LARGE
\boldmath{$\gamma$}
\end{center}

Measures the amount of agglomeration in an industry above and beyond what we would expect.
\vspace{1cm}

Main results: Manufacturing industries show strong evidence of low levels of agglomeration. (Gamma between 0 and .6 for majority of industries.)

##Simulation Conclusions
Gamma seems to be:
\begin{itemize} \itemsep2em
  \item Sensitive to scale
  \item Sensitive to industry differences
  \item Sensitive to size of sector
\end{itemize}

Does gamma really measure what we want?

##DGS vs EG Metrics
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width = 1\textwidth]{"../DGSMetricReplication/Output/gammaalpha".jpg}
\end{center}
Overall correlation: .2126 \newline
Positive value correlation: .9822

#Conclusion

##Conclusion
\begin{itemize}\itemsep2em
  \item{Both metrics confirm that nonprofits differ widely in how they agglomerate or disperse.}
  \item{Nonprofit sectors behave very differently.}
  \item{The much simpler DGS metric seems to do just as well at showing agglomeration, and may also show dispersion accurately.}
\end{itemize}
